commit_message:
fullstack: Compile openvswitch module for fullstack test

After switching to UCA, we started getting ovs 2.5.2. There was a
condition that compiled openvswitch only if the version was lower than
2.5.1. This patch always compiles only kernel part of openvswitch so we
get VXLAN tunnelling working with fullstack.

Closes-bug: 1684897

Change-Id: I13898fc661d590609d2ef40873daef987956db6b
(cherry picked from commit 70b82034aca8865c423e91cde6ce826cc4c617a1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/458760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # prepare_for_compilation() - Fetch ovs git repository and install packages needed for # compilation. function prepare_for_compilation {} # reload_kernel_modules() - reload openvswitch kernel module function reload_kernel_modules { sudo modprobe -r vport_geneve sudo modprobe -r openvswitch load_module openvswitch load_module vport-geneve False dmesg | tail } # compile_ovs() - Compile OVS from source and load needed modules. # Accepts two parameters: # - first one is True by default and means that modules are built and installed. # - second optional parameter defines prefix for ovs compilation # - third optional parameter defines localstatedir for ovs single machine runtime # Env variables OVS_REPO_NAME, OVS_REPO and OVS_BRANCH must be set function compile_ovs { local _pwd=$PWD local build_modules=${1:-True} local prefix=$2 local localstatedir=$3 if [ -n "$prefix" ]; then prefix="--prefix=$prefix" fi if [ -n "$localstatedir" ]; then localstatedir="--localstatedir=$localstatedir" fi prepare_for_compilation reload_kernel_modules# action_service - call an action over openvswitch service # Accepts one parameter that can be either # 'start', 'restart' and 'stop'. function action_openvswitch { local action=$1 if is_ubuntu; then ${action}_service openvswitch-switch elif is_fedora; then ${action}_service openvswitch elif is_suse; then if [[ $DISTRO == "sle12" ]] && [[ $os_RELEASE -lt 12.2 ]]; then ${action}_service openvswitch-switch else ${action}_service openvswitch fi fi } # compile_ovs_kernel_module() - Compile openvswitch kernel module and load it function compile_ovs_kernel_module { local _pwd=$PWD prepare_for_compilation [ -f configure ] || ./boot.sh if [ ! -f config.status ] || [ configure -nt config.status ] ; then ./configure --with-linux=/lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build fi action_openvswitch stop make -j$[$(nproc) + 1] sudo make INSTALL_MOD_DIR=kernel/net/openvswitch modules_install if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then reload_kernel_modules else echo "Compiling OVS kernel module failed" fi action_openvswitch start cd $_pwd }
deleted_lines: # compile_ovs() - Compile OVS from source and load needed modules. # Accepts two parameters: # - first one is True by default and means that modules are built and installed. # - second optional parameter defines prefix for ovs compilation # - third optional parameter defines localstatedir for ovs single machine runtime # Env variables OVS_REPO_NAME, OVS_REPO and OVS_BRANCH must be set function compile_ovs { local _pwd=$PWD local build_modules=${1:-True} local prefix=$2 local localstatedir=$3 if [ -n "$prefix" ]; then prefix="--prefix=$prefix" fi if [ -n "$localstatedir" ]; then localstatedir="--localstatedir=$localstatedir" fi sudo modprobe -r vport_geneve sudo modprobe -r openvswitch load_module openvswitch load_module vport-geneve False dmesg | tail

commit_message:
Revert "Generate placeholders for resource proxies before validation"

This reverts commit f94d76cb322f14a001e7990c0918a67f1a09ea16.

All stack deployments in TripleO are taking about 10
minutes longer, so 20 minutes for ovb-updates job.

We found out that it's partially related to this patch.
See details in the bug report.

https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1684272

Change-Id: I80ced2dbc9127bc1501f8729eb52195c0d206813
Partial-Bug: #1684272

commit_message:
Change auth_version to v3 on Tempest

Keystone v3 API is CURRENT and the v2 API is deprecated now.
So we need to change the default config of auth_version to fit
for current API status.

Change-Id: I801e6740258ddea2a1b628a209970e0307d39d12
(cherry picked from commit dc6e55021861afceae2a7778b299df94ceab0a6e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/00/458800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG identity auth_version ${TEMPEST_AUTH_VERSION:-v3}
deleted_lines: iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG identity auth_version ${TEMPEST_AUTH_VERSION:-v2} # Use v3 auth tokens for running all Tempest tests iniset $TEMPEST_CONFIG identity auth_version v3

commit_message:
Fix: the tox cover job was not updating coverage report.

This patch updates the cover command to remove older coverage
reports before running.

Change-Id: I31f8d11c2c1fd9f8b36ee8090f321020e48c60d3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/50/458150/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = rm -f *.pyc rm -rf cover rm -f .coverage nosetests {posargs} rm

Only bind haproxy to internal IP, repo and galera

commit_message:
Deriving TripleO Parameters

With the introspection data of the nodes available, it is possible
to run pre-calculated formulas, to derive the deployment parameters
to ease the deployment steps for complex features. Mistral workflow
is used to create this formulas. This spec explains all details
around it.
blueprint tripleo-derive-parameters

Co-Authored-By: Saravanan KR <skramaja@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Id49af12ae9943f0c2907e44c9647d557743b205f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/04/423304/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================ TripleO Performance Profiles ============================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-performance-profiles Add the ability to save a set of Overcloud tunings in a Performance Profile in Heat and provide a list of predefined tunings to help operators easily deploy an Overcloud that is already tuned for a particular type of workload, i.e. "tuned for TripleO". Problem Description =================== OpenStack clouds can run workloads more efficiently when information about the available hardware and the specific workload can be analyzed and trade-offs are made in the system configuration to optimize for a particular result. This proposal aims to make these types of system tuning tasks easier by enabling operators to do the following: * Easily deploy an Overcloud pre-tuned for a particular workload simply by referencing a single performance profile from a list * Create a framework in Heat for performance profiles which allows operators to more clearly define performance tunings * Make it easy for operators to share and extend performance profiles * Capture systems tuning expertise in a Mistral workflow An operator may use TripleO to tune for a workload by overriding many parameters in Heat, but the operator may not know which parameters to override for a particular workload. The process to come up with what values to provide in Heat may be complex in itself and involve applying formulas provided by systems tuning experts. The proposal aims to automate this process. Proposed Change =============== Deployment ---------- A new Heat environment file called workload_profiles.yaml would be shipped in TripleO that a deployer may optionally choose to use with a command like the following:: openstack overcloud deploy --templates \ -e /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/workload_profiles.yaml \ -e ~/my_templates/workload.yaml where ~/my_templates/workload.yaml contains something like the following:: parameter_defaults: WorkloadProfile: 'hci_enterprise_many_small_vms' This example uses HCI, running Ceph OSD and Nova Compute on the same node, but proposal aims to provide a framework to solve the generic problem of characterizing a workload and deploying an overcloud that is already tuned for that workload. Mistral Workflow ---------------- Given the deployment command above, TripleO would create a new Workload Heat resource, introduced by the implementation described here. This new resource would create a OS::Mistral::WorflowExecution [1]_ which would affect the deployment. The parameter called hci_enterprise_many_small_vms would be used to look up the following parameters from the new workload_profiles.yaml, which would look something like the following:: resource_registry: OS::TripleO::Tasks::WorkloadProfile: ../extraconfig/tasks/workload-profile-workflow.yaml parameter_defaults: hci_enterprise_default: workload::average_guest_flavor: 'm1.medium' workload::average_guest_memory_size_in_mb: 2048 workload::average_guest_CPU_utilization_percentage: 50 workload::tuned_profile: 'throughput-performance' workload::jumbo_frames: storage_mgmt_nic # does not support updates workload::numa_service:: ceph-osd@.service workload::numa_nic:: storage_mgmt_nic workload::numa_policy:: preferred hci_enterprise_many_small_vms: workload::average_guest_flavor: 'm1.small' workload::average_guest_memory_size_in_mb: 1024 workload::average_guest_CPU_utilization_percentage: 20 workload::tuned_profile: 'throughput-performance' workload::jumbo_frames: storage_mgmt_nic # does not support updates workload::numa_service:: ceph-osd@.service workload::numa_nic:: storage_mgmt_nic workload::numa_policy:: preferred hci_enterprise_few_large_vms: workload::average_guest_flavor: 'm1.xlarge' workload::average_guest_memory_size_in_mb: 4096 workload::average_guest_CPU_utilization_percentage: 80 workload::tuned_profile: 'throughput-performance' workload::jumbo_frames: storage_mgmt_nic # does not support updates workload::numa_service:: ceph-osd@.service workload::numa_nic:: storage_mgmt_nic workload::numa_policy:: preferred hci_nfv_default: workload::average_guest_flavor: 'm1.large' workload::average_guest_memory_size_in_mb: 8192 workload::average_guest_CPU_utilization_percentage: 90 workload::tuned_profile: 'latency-performance' workload::jumbo_frames: storage_mgmt_nic # does not support updates The list of parameters under hci_enterprise_many_small_vms would be passed to the Mistral workflow in workload-profile-workflow.yaml. The workload workflow would then use its parameters to compute additional parameters. An example of its computations may be found in nova_mem_cpu_calc.py [2]_, which was written by performance engineers who tested OpenStack/Ceph in a lab under load to determine equations to tune an HCI deployment per workload. As previously stated, this example is for HCI but the proposal, if implemented, would provide a framework to allow others to automate workload tuning logic. The script behaves as follows:: $ ./nova_mem_cpu_calc.py 256 56 10 2 0.1 Inputs: - Total host RAM in GB: 256 - Total host cores: 56 - Ceph OSDs per host: 10 - Average guest memory size in GB: 2 - Average guest CPU utilization: 10% Results: - number of guests allowed based on memory = 90 - number of guest vCPUs allowed = 460 - nova.conf reserved_host_memory = 181000 MB - nova.conf cpu_allocation_ratio = 8.214286 Compare "guest vCPUs allowed" to "guests allowed based on memory" for actual guest count $ The hardware properties above may be looked up in the Ironic DB and the other properties, e.g. Ceph OSDs per host, may be looked up in Heat environment variables. The average guest memory size and the CPU utilization percentage would be provided by workload_profiles.yaml. The logic contained in the script would be executed by Mistral to arrive at the desired parameters. The parameters would then be provided to the Overcloud deployment. In the context of the above example, the deployment would be identical to a deployment where the following Heat environment file had been passed in place of the workload environment files:: parameter_defaults: ExtraConfig: nova::compute::reserved_host_memory: 181000 nova::cpu_allocation_ratio: 8.2 and the nova.conf on the existing overcloud would reflect the values above. Though the above example only produces two parameters of output for one of input (WorkloadProfile: 'hci_enterprise_many_small_vms'), many other tunings could be abstracted from the deployer and applied to any of the OpenStack configurations that TripleO manages and thus the deployer would be able to easily change a variety of parameters by changing only one parameter. More beneficial than this however, is that the formula to tune the overcloud deployemnt, relative to its workload, would be captured in the deployment tool and the deployer wouldn't need to know all of the details. In addition, a tuning, or set of parameters, per workload could be captured in workload_profiles.yaml and shipped with TripleO as well as extended and shared. Applying Mistral Generated Parameters to the Overcloud ------------------------------------------------------ In order for the resulting parameters to be applied to the overcloud, the deployment plan, which is stored in Swift on the undercloud, should be modified. This would be the last thing that the workload workflow does. The process to do this is analogous to how TripleO uses Jina2 templates to compute certain parameters but Mistral would be computing them instead of Jinja2. One way to do this is to have the Mistral workflow generate the Heat environment files automatically and take advantage of the fact that the last environment file passed overrides the previous ones and have the deployment pass those environment files as the last set of parameters. <WIP> Any suggestions on how to best update the overcloud deployment plan? Can Mistral use the python-tripleoclient's _upload_templates [3]_? </WIP> Regarding Parameter Repetition ------------------------------ It should be possible to define a parameter in a performance profile that TripleO already supports and would usually be passed as any other TripleO parameter. Relating this back to the HCI example, the following setting benefits an HCI deployment (by prioritizing for consistent performance on OSD failure over a faster recovery time), and so could have been included in the example in workload_profiles.yaml:: ceph::profile::params::osd_recovery_op_priority: 2 In this respect the Mistral workflow would contain an identity function which simply passes on the parameter instead of using additional logic to compute a parameter. The same idea applies to storing an MTU parameter in a performance profile but a variation in that the setting is made a different way to avoid hard coding a value that may vary in a performance profile. Normally the MTU can be set for a particular NIC with an entry like the following under OsNetConfigImpl:: config: os_net_config: network_config: - type: interface name: em2 use_dhcp: false mtu: 9000 - type: vlan device: nic2 # or em2 mtu: 9000 use_dhcp: false vlan_id: {get_param: StorageMgmtNetworkVlanID} The above assumes that the deployer knows that nic2 is what should be set to MTU 9000. This type of detail is not abstract enough to specify in a performance profile so that it is portable because nic2 is hard coded. The following example in workload_profiles.yaml would set the above after it determined that the storage management NIC was em2 based on a version of the above that doesn't include the MTU setting; which is appropriate to assume for a TripleO user to set:: workload::jumbo_frames: storage_mgmt_nic # does not support updates The comment that the above does not support updates is there to remind users that network configurations are set only on create as per TripleO's default. Regarding parameters not yet implemented in openstack-puppet ------------------------------------------------------------ The example workload_profiles.yaml included the following:: workload::tuned_profile: 'throughput-performance' The above would set the tuned profile of all overcloud nodes to throughput-performance. This feature is not yet implemented in puppet-openstack but could be implemented either independently or as part of this spec. Alternatively, this could be set using a pre-network hook [4]_ Similarly, the following were listed in workload_profiles.yaml:: workload::numa_nic: storage_mgmt_nic workload::numa_service: ceph-osd@.service workload::numa_policy: preferred <FOOT> The above would use the same Mistral workflow described previously to identify the storage_mgmt_nic, as described in the previous section, and then identify that NIC's NUMA node. This is possible today by using lstopo-no-graphics (which isn't on the overcloud image currently) or better yet will be possible as per a proposed feature in Ironic to retrieve that information during introspection [5]_. The above would use workload::numa_service to find the appropriate service in /usr/lib/systemd/system/ and make a copy of it in /etc/systemd/ which it would then modify to append the following to:: NUMA="/usr/bin/numactl -N $NUMASOCKET --preferred=$NUMASOCKET" The workload::numa_policy of preferred was chosen based on the parameter instead of membind (or other valid options for numactl). The numactl would need to be included in the overcloud image for this example to work. There is a post-deploy script to do this work today [6]_ but a better implementation could be done in puppet-ceph as it is a Ceph specific change. The above points out a distinction between workload parameters and the type of parameters currently found in TripleO. The above changes would happen in support of but independently of this spec and thus there would be THT changes for them if they were merged. What is described in this spec would then be a reference to call those changes as part of a workload profile. Depending on the timing, the four parameters described in this spec could be implemented in the future. Future intregration with TripleO UI ----------------------------------- If this spec were implemented and merged, then the TripleO UI could have a menu item for a deployment, e.g. HCI, in which the deployer may choose a performance profile and then deploy an overcloud with that performance profile. The UI could better integrate with this feature by allowing a deployer to use a graphical slider to vary an existing performance profile and then save that performance profile with a new name. The following cycle could be used by the deployer to tune the overcloud. * Choose a deployment, e.g. HCI * Choose a performance profile, e.g. hci_enterprise_many_small_vms * Run the deployment * Benchmark the planned workload on the deployed overcloud * Use the sliders to change aspects of the performance profile * Update the deployment and re-run the benchmark * Repeat as needed * Save the new performance profile as the one to be deployed in the field The implementation of this spec would enable the TripleO UI to support the above. Alternatives ------------ The simplest alternative is for operators to determine what tunings are appropriate by testing or reading documentation and then implement those tunings in the appropriate Heat environment files. For example, an operator could run nova_mem_cpu_calc.py (see URL in references) and then create a Heat enviornment file like the following with its output and then deploy the overcloud and directly reference this file:: parameter_defaults: ExtraConfig: nova::compute::reserved_host_memory: 181000 nova::cpu_allocation_ratio: 8.2 This could translate into a variety of overrides which would require initiative on the operator's part. Another alternative is to write separate tools which generate the desired Heat templates but don't integrate them with TripleO. For example, nova_mem_cpu_calc.py and similar, would produce a set of Heat environment files as output which the operator would then include instead of output containing the following: * nova.conf reserved_host_memory_mb = 181000 MB * nova.conf cpu_allocation_ratio = 8.214286 When evaluating the above, keep in mind that only two parameters for CPU alloction and memory are being provided as an example, but that a tuned deployment may contain many more. Security Impact --------------- There is no security impact from this change as it sits at a higher level to automate, via Mistral and Heat, features that already exist. Other End User Impact --------------------- There is no end user impact as this change is focussed on operators. The change may benefit end users but the end user would not use this new feature directly. Performance Impact ------------------ The deployment and update of an overcloud may take slightly longer if an operator uses this feature becuase an additional Mistral workflow needs to run to perform some analytics before applying configuration updates. However, the performance of the overcloud would be improved because this proposal aims to make it easier to tune the overcloud for performance. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- A new configuration option is being added, but it has to be explicitly enabled, and thus it would not take immediate effect after its merged. Though, if a deployer chooses to use it and there is a bug in it, then it could affect the overcloud deployment. If a deployer uses this new option, and had a deploy in which they set a parameter directly, e.g. the Nova cpu_allocation_ratio, then that parameter may be overridden by a particular tuning profile. So that is something a deployer should be aware of when using this proposed feature. The config options being added will ship with a variety of defaults based on deployments put under load in a lab. The main idea is to make different sets of defaults, which were produced under these conditions, available. The example discussed in this proposal and to be made available on completion could be extended. Developer Impact ---------------- <WIP>Depending on how the changes are applied to the deployment plan, it could have other developer impact. This needs to be investigated. However, it would only impact them if they used the feature and it had a bug.</WIP> Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: fultonj Other contributors: gfidente Work Items ---------- * Define a dictionary of performance tuning profiles * Create a new Heat Resource in THT which starts an independent Mistral workflow to query Ironic, apply formulas, and set desired values in Heat to be used during the rest of the deployment * <WIP>Apply the desired values to the deployment plan</WIP> * Update THT to support the new performance profiles Dependencies ============ * None; it could be used by the TripleO-UI but doesn't depend on it. Testing ======= Create a new scenario in the TripleO CI in which a deployment is done using all of the available options within a performance profile called all-performance-options. A CI test would need to be added that would test this new feature by doing the following: * A deployment would be done with the all-performance-options profile * The deployment would be checked that all of the configs had been made * If the config changes are in place, then the test passed * Else the test failed Relating the above back to the example provided earlier, the test could verify one of two options: 1. A Heat environment file created with the following syntactically valid Heat:: parameter_defaults: ExtraConfig: nova::compute::reserved_host_memory: 181000 nova::cpu_allocation_ratio: 8.2 2. The compute node was deployed such that the commands below return something like the following:: [root@overcloud-osd-compute-0 ~]# grep reserved_host_memory /etc/nova/nova.conf reserved_host_memory_mb=181000 [root@overcloud-osd-compute-0 ~]# grep cpu_allocation_ratio /etc/nova/nova.conf cpu_allocation_ratio=8.2 [root@overcloud-osd-compute-0 ~]# Option 1 would put less load on the CI infrastructure and produce a faster test but Option 2 tests the full scenario. If a new performance option is added, then the all-performance-options profile would need to be updated and the test would need to be updated to verify that the new options were set. Documentation Impact ==================== A new chapter would be added to the TripleO document on deploying with performance profiles. References ========== .. [1] `OS::Mistral::WorflowExecution spec <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/267770>`_ and `OS::Mistral::WorflowExecution example <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/420664>`_ .. [2] `nova_mem_cpu_calc.py <https://github.com/RHsyseng/hci/blob/master/scripts/nova_mem_cpu_calc.py>`_ .. [3] `python-tripleoclient's _upload_templates <https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/5.7.0/tripleoclient/workflows/plan_management.py#L29-L42>`_ .. [4] `Pre-network hook to set tuned profile <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/411797>`_ .. [5] `Spec for Ironic to retrieve NUMA node info <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/396147>`_ .. [6] `numa-systemd-osd.sh <https://github.com/RHsyseng/hci/blob/master/custom-templates/numa-systemd-osd.sh>`_

commit_message:
Remove log translation related check

Since we're preparing to remove log translation from project, we
should remove translation check to ensure tests pass.

Change-Id: Ic877142ba46621a69c3718c5ef5b79fc7f742315
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cloudkitty refs/changes/81/451381/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: - [C313] Validate that debug level logs are not translated.- [C315] Translated messages cannot be concatenated. String should be included in translated message. - [C316] Log messages, except debug ones, require translations!- [C321] Ensure that the _() function is explicitly imported to ensure proper translations. LOG Translations ---------------- LOG.debug messages will not get translated. Use ``_LI()`` for ``LOG.info``, ``_LW`` for ``LOG.warning``, ``_LE`` for ``LOG.error`` and ``LOG.exception``, and ``_LC()`` for ``LOG.critical``. ``_()`` is preferred for any user facing message, even if it is also going to a log file. This ensures that the translated version of the message will be available to the user. The log marker functions (``_LI()``, ``_LW()``, ``_LE()``, and ``_LC()``) must only be used when the message is only sent directly to the log. Anytime that the message will be passed outside of the current context (for example as part of an exception) the ``_()`` marker function must be used. A common pattern is to define a single message object and use it more than once, for the log call and the exception. In that case, ``_()`` must be used because the message is going to appear in an exception that may be presented to the user. For more details about translations, see http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html

commit_message:
Add Toolbar component and filters state

* Adds Toolbar components
* Adds Toolbar specific inputs
* Adds DropdownSelect input and DropdownKebab
* Adds NodesToolbar component which is rendered in
  RegisteredNodesTabPane
* Adds filters handling. Filters are produced by toolbars
  and can be used in selectors to filter data
* Adds universal ToolbarFiltersForm which handles adding Active
  filters
* Wires NodesToolbar filter with Registered Nodes list

Change-Id: Ida591a026031362987180f0cc4f20ae30e887272
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ui refs/changes/75/452175/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import filtersReducer from './filtersReducer'; filters: filtersReducer,

commit_message:
Adding subunit files to artcl_collect_list

Tempest Periodic job uses ovb-settings.yml instead of
toci-quickstart/config/collect-logs.yml
so it's required to update the artcl_collect_list here in order to be

commit_message:
Configure migration SSH tunnel

This patch configures SSH tunneling for nova cold-migration and reuses the
tunnel for libvirt live-migration unless TLS has been enabled.

Change-Id: I367757cbe8757d11943af7e41af620f9ce919a06
Depends-On: Iac1763761c652bed637cb7cf85bc12347b5fe7ec
(cherry picked from commit ccbcd11276c7bc3ffc8f013d9a5b2d3944bf76cf)

commit_message:
Allow to configure haproxy daemon's status

Currently we hard-code the fact that haproxy starts as a daemon.
When running haproxy in a container we need this to be configurable
because the haproxy process will be pid number 1.

We are not changing the current semantics which have the 'daemon'
option always set, but we are allowing its disabling.

Change-Id: I51c482b70731f15fee4025bbce14e46a49a49938
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/25/458025/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*haproxy_daemon*] # Should haproxy run in daemon mode or not # Defaults to true # $haproxy_daemon = true, $haproxy_global_options = { 'log' => "${haproxy_log_address} local0", 'pidfile' => '/var/run/haproxy.pid', 'user' => 'haproxy', 'group' => 'haproxy', 'maxconn' => $haproxy_global_maxconn, 'ssl-default-bind-ciphers' => $ssl_cipher_suite, 'ssl-default-bind-options' => $ssl_options, 'stats' => [ 'socket /var/lib/haproxy/stats mode 600 level user', 'timeout 2m' ], } if $haproxy_daemon == true { $haproxy_daemonize = { 'daemon' => '', } } else { $haproxy_daemonize = {} } global_options => merge($haproxy_global_options, $haproxy_daemonize),

The custom start scripting for the nova compute service assumed that the

commit_message:
Fix libvirt group selection in live migration test

The custom start scripting for the nova compute service assumed that the
libvirt group is "libvirtd". Unforately libvirtd is no longer used by
debuntu as they use "libvirt". Add a simple check against /etc/group
for an existing libvirtd user otherwise use libvirt.

Change-Id: Idbda49587f3b62a0870d10817291205bde0e821e
Depends-On: If2dbc53d082fea779448998ea12b821bd037a14e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/456408/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Determine what the libvirt is. If there is a group called "libvirtd" # in /etc/groups use that, otherwise default to "libvirt". # Note, new ubuntu and debian use libvirt, everything else is libvirtd. local libvirt_group libvirt_group=$(cut -d ':' -f 1 /etc/group | grep 'libvirtd$' || true) libvirt_group=${libvirt_group:-libvirt} sudo -H -u $STACK_USER bash -c "/tmp/start_process.sh n-cpu '/usr/local/bin/nova-compute --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf' $libvirt_group" ssh $SUBNODE "sudo -H -u $STACK_USER bash -c '/tmp/start_process.sh n-cpu \"/usr/local/bin/nova-compute --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf\" $libvirt_group'"
deleted_lines: sudo -H -u $STACK_USER bash -c "/tmp/start_process.sh n-cpu '/usr/local/bin/nova-compute --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf' libvirtd" ssh $SUBNODE "sudo -H -u $STACK_USER bash -c '/tmp/start_process.sh n-cpu \"/usr/local/bin/nova-compute --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf\" libvirtd'"

commit_message:
Use -net=host for docker-puppet.py config gen

We pass the short hostname to docker-puppet.py. In order to satisfy the
factor FQDN check for the short hostname we need to run the container
with --net=host in some cases.

Change-Id: I2929f122f23ee33e8ea5d4c5006d2bbb8b928b67
Closes-bug: #1681903

commit_message:
Add description to policies in security_groups.py

The 'discoverable' policy is not documented as it will be removed in a
future change.

blueprint policy-docs

commit_message:
Add support for namespaces into context manager

Add some filtering login based on namespaces to the ContextManager.
It allows us to:
* execute the proper context(in case of having several "users" contexts
  it is very important feature)
* execute two and more contexts with equal names.

Change-Id: I39fa864426869d95ee135e575ff2982b4545716c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/16/458116/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from rally import exceptions context_list = [] for ctx_name in self.context_obj["config"].keys(): if "@" in ctx_name: ctx_name, ctx_namespace = ctx_name.split("@", 1) context_list.append(Context.get(ctx_name, namespace=ctx_namespace)) else: potential_result = Context.get_all(ctx_name) if len(potential_result) == 1: context_list.append(potential_result[0]) continue elif len(potential_result) > 1: scen_namespace = self.context_obj["scenario_namespace"] another_attempt = [c for c in potential_result if c.get_namespace() == scen_namespace] if another_attempt: context_list.append(another_attempt[0]) continue another_attempt = [c for c in potential_result if c.get_namespace() == "default"] if another_attempt: context_list.append(another_attempt[0]) continue raise exceptions.PluginNotFound(name=ctx_name, namespace="any of") return sorted(context_list)
deleted_lines: return sorted([ Context.get(ctx_name, namespace=self.context_obj["scenario_namespace"], allow_hidden=True)(self.context_obj) for ctx_name in self.context_obj["config"].keys()])

Vagrantfile: Switch to openSUSE Leap 42.2

openSUSE Leap 42.1 will soon be EOL. However, openSUSE Leap 42.2
Vagrant images are now available on Atlas so use these instead.

commit_message:
[WIP] Test Python 2.7.13 on CentOS

Initial tests show that Python 2.7.5 on CentOS 7 causes some slowdowns
in certain Ansible tasks, including yum/pip tasks. This patch is a test
to see if installing 2.7.13 in the gate has any effect on the
performance.

Change-Id: Ifd856abfaa1494a55f11c12c99db483e9f9280a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests refs/changes/57/458657/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## Test Python 2.7.13 on CentOS ---------------------------------------------- if [ -e '/etc/centos-release']; then yum -y install "@Development Tools" python-devel readline-devel \ sqlite-devel sqlite2-devel bzip2-devel cd /tmp wget https://www.python.org/ftp/python/2.7.13/Python-2.7.13.tgz tar xf Python-2.7.13.tgz cd Python-2.7.13 ./configure make install python --version ansible-playbook --version fi

commit_message:
Add defaults for docker puppet tasks

Currently we're referencing some steps that don't exist in the
output from the OS::Heat::Value resource, but as noted in the heat
bug #1681749 I think this isn't valid and probably should not be
allowed, so instead merge defaults with the non-empty step
tasks. To avoid further duplication of the loop variables, I
made the max step a variable.

Change-Id: Icf3d639b53c97006a0c370c12600449fba6f3323
Related-Bug: #1681749
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/18/455718/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $.data.default_tasks + dict($.data.docker_puppet_tasks.where($1 != null).selectMany($.items()).groupBy($[0], $[1])) default_tasks: {%- for step in range(1, 6) %} step_{{step}}: {} {% endfor -%}

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-20 14:31:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/2f4c811b239de8e499a1ca19ebd14a066d168980', 'message': "N->O Manual puppet commands have the right modulepath.

commit_message:
N->O Manual puppet commands have the right modulepath.

In two places during upgrade we manually trigger puppet.

There can be a problem when new puppet modules are added, and their
corresponding symlinks in /etc/puppet/modules are not created during
the installation as their are installed in
/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules.  To prevent the issue tripleo set
modulepath in the templates.

We must use the same modulepath to make sure that we don't fail
because of missing module in the manual puppet run.

This particulary happens when you upgrade from M->N->O, as the base
image in Mitaka doesn't have the proper symlinks and they are not
created during the installation of the package.

Closes-Bug: #1684587

Change-Id: I79df6ea33f1c58e13309176a6de41b7572541fd6
(cherry picked from commit 79c2d0f3d411da9e57731d9da79d25a3e0364eb2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/30/458530/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: command: puppet apply --modulepath /etc/puppet/modules:/opt/stack/puppet-modules:/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules --detailed-exitcodes /root/nova-api_upgrade_manifest.pp

subject: Remove unneeded validation code in ValidateInterfacesHook
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-18 11:08:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/cbf8c662d02e1eefd9a2c094546dc37656dbe333', 'message': 'Actively set enforce_type=False in unit tests that require it

Tests in TestValidateInterfacesHookLoad set config options to an
invalid value, hoping that ValidateInterfacesHook will find that
error and fail accordingly. This no longer happens with oslo.config
after [1].

As a fix to allow unit tests to pass with a new oslo.config release,
set enforce_type=False in those tests. A more complete solution will
require removing the unneeded check code.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/328692

Closes-Bug: #1683732
Change-Id: I5830466cb21f200ae1c33021cce4d166a26456be
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-19 12:39:57.000000000', 'files': ['ironic_inspector/test/unit/test_plugins_standard.py', 'ironic_inspector/plugins/standard.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector/commit/dffdf36ebd08eb8ed2c5f2cc03b5a7f3dba38927', 'message': 'Remove unneeded validation code in ValidateInterfacesHook

oslo.config now sets enforce_type=True by default since [1], so
there is no need to check in ValidateInterfacesHook that the value
set in the config file is one of the valid values.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/328692

Closes-Bug: #1683732
Change-Id: I5830466cb21f200ae1c33021cce4d166a26456be
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unneeded validation code in ValidateInterfacesHook

oslo.config now sets enforce_type=True by default since [1], so
there is no need to check in ValidateInterfacesHook that the value
set in the config file is one of the valid values.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/328692

Closes-Bug: #1683732
Change-Id: I5830466cb21f200ae1c33021cce4d166a26456be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/72/457572/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.set_override('add_ports', 'foobar', 'processing', enforce_type=False) CONF.set_override('keep_ports', 'foobar', 'processing', enforce_type=False)

subject: Fix create, update or delete account metadata method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-12 08:55:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/a40f4b631d8c39377fc6988850be5203e62f35f2', 'message': 'Fix create, update or delete account metadata method

Swift provides a single API to Create, Update or Delete
account metadata.
With different headers or values those operation can be
achieved. For example:
- delete metadata by passing metadata without value
- update metadata by passing updated value with same key

Details- http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/object-storage/?expanded=create-update-or-delete-account-metadata-detail

But current service client for account has 3 different
method for these operation. create_, delete_ and create_and_delete_

To make it consistent with other service client and to have
single service client method per API, this patch merge those
methods.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I098e4ccc0d7b443d77ee055f39958e983acf7113
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-13 03:44:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/887965d729e9358aae48992af4f653fd7364a9fc', 'message': 'Fix create, update or delete account metadata method

commit_message:
Fix create, update or delete account metadata method

Swift provides a single API to Create, Update or Delete
account metadata.
With different headers or values those operation can be
achieved. For example:
- delete metadata by passing metadata without value
- update metadata by passing updated value with same key

Details- http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/object-storage/?expanded=create-update-or-delete-account-metadata-detail

But current service client for account has 3 different
method for these operation. create_, delete_ and create_and_delete_

To make it consistent with other service client and to have
single service client method per API, this patch merge those
methods.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I098e4ccc0d7b443d77ee055f39958e983acf7113
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/70/409670/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Generate placeholders for resource proxies before validation

Before validating resources, generate placeholder NodeData for them in the
StackDefinition. Currently, all attributes are given a value of None
(consistent with how the get_attr intrinsic functions substitute them when
the resource state indicates that the attributes are not valid now).
Reference IDs are generated as usual (since the logic for what to return
when the state indicates the data are not valid is contained in the
resource plugins).

In the long term, this should help us to remove the state-checking logic
from the intrinsic functions.

In the short term, this allows us to validate template data that is parsed
against the StackDefinition (rather than the Stack), since it gives us a
list of valid attribute names.

In the medium term, this should give us a place to substitute in more
sophisticated placeholder values to do better validation.

Change-Id: I154ff0cd019d279379886fccbd708cf0d39ce53f

commit_message:
Properly handle shared storage during live migration

After a live migration is performed, we always try to delete the
instance files.

If the migration fails, the destination node is not cleaned up as
the HyperVLiveMigrateData object is not used at the moment and the
nova compute manager won't know whether a cleanup is needed or not.

Also, in order to support using CSVs for storing instance files, we
need to explicitly specify whether image files will be migrated or not
when requesting os-win to migrate the VM.

This change addresses those issues.

NOTE(claudiub): the HyperVLiveMigrateData object version in Mitaka
is 1.0, causing a unit test to fail. The unit test has been slightly
changed to address this issue.

Depends-On: I48dc6da29534bf0c477c742311ac15438d8b63ad

Change-Id: Icf2f258ef8900b5970ff153a7b981ee53e58dd2d
Partial-Bug: #1565895
(cherry picked from commit e2d304810fb4eac15f73959abc3a434975904ff5)

commit_message:
Require os-brick>=1.11.0

Required by Nova change I37ffc90c0bd57029fced251b5cfd7cd4318a0292 that
aims to remove encryptor code from the codebase in favor of the same
duplicated code provided by the 1.11.0 Ocata release of os-brick.

Implements: blueprint switch-to-os-brick-encryptor-classes
Change-Id: I0c54ecec586a7c30b28855545cbad8e1c1888c77

Change-Id: I11a2220283d27d3d65248287b90c7f4455d11e9a

commit_message:
Detect httpd on openSUSE/SLES

The apache2 process name on openSUSE might be 'httpd-prefork'. Otherwise
while running monasca-setup, the error is:

      ERROR: Apache process does not exist.

Change-Id: I11a2220283d27d3d65248287b90c7f4455d11e9a
(cherry picked from commit 56ff5b04da2eca9ff33ec8098ecb9e40e2b761b0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/63/458363/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Process name is apache2 on Debian derivatives, on RHEL derivatives it's httpd, # on openSUSE/SLES it might be httpd-prefork APACHE_PROCESS_NAMES = ('apache2', 'httpd', 'httpd-prefork')
deleted_lines: # Process name is apache2 on Debian derivatives, on RHEL derivatives it's httpd APACHE_PROCESS_NAMES = ('apache2', 'httpd')

commit_message:
Adding labels support to Storm

Adding support to labels to the Storm plugin as well as marking storm
version 0.9.2 as deprecated.

commit_message:
openstack-monasca-agent: various fixes

* Fixed enabling-disabling systemd service
* Fixed permissions
* Create rundir for tmpfiles (we need this because
  /run is mounted as tmpfs sometimes).
* Write pid file in systemd service.
* Create /sbin/rcopenstack-monasca-agent symlink on SUSE
* Restricted sudoers file to just the privileges actually required
  by checks.

(cherry picked from commit 5cccfc040bbc73e642f3a84125dc43bb62ad3d4f)

Depends-On: I827b2b1f80866855c336a464d78ddfbaaeb0133b
Change-Id: I49a82805491235aa118b3d8482330b97dc232c01
Co-Authored-By: Thomas Bechtold <tbechtold@suse.com>

commit_message:
Use 'basename' filter for source

When tracking stable branches, use the basename filter to set the RPM
Source tag to a local file instead of an url.
This is useful on the SUSE side because the OpenBuildService tries to
download the tarball again but this tarball could have changed meanwhile.

Depends-On: I00c8c823af35340de0aff479a4f05e1d077613ee
Change-Id: I827b2b1f80866855c336a464d78ddfbaaeb0133b

commit_message:
Remove some codes of older version builder

Building CDH image under version 5.5.0 is no longer support.
Remove these useless code.
Also, adding the ambari usage info in sahara-image-create
command.

Change-Id: I6fffe25ee9daf651355611be675137babb67e2a8

subject: Fix 'navigator-keytrustee' repo not found error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-17 06:59:39.000000000', 'files': ['elements/hadoop-cloudera/pre-install.d/10-add-mirror'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/sahara-image-elements/commit/105577b6ca7edde849a288b4b09994507ae587ae', 'message': "Fix 'navigator-keytrustee' repo not found error

Build an image with DIB_CDH_MINOR_VERSION may fail
because `navigator-keytrustee` doesn't release
minor version sometimes, and then the repo will not
be found.
This patch determines whether the repo exists before
writing repo url.

Change-Id: I6bcd66264019847a08c2ba4c15da401567e57574
Closes-Bug: 1682754
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 'navigator-keytrustee' repo not found error

Build an image with DIB_CDH_MINOR_VERSION may fail
because `navigator-keytrustee` doesn't release
minor version sometimes, and then the repo will not
be found.
This patch determines whether the repo exists before
writing repo url.

Change-Id: I6bcd66264019847a08c2ba4c15da401567e57574
Closes-Bug: 1682754

account/password information

commit_message:
Add special case upgrade from openvswitch 2.5.0-14

In [1] we removed the previously used special case upgrade code.
However we have since discovered that for openvswitch 2.5.0-14
the special case is still required with an extra flag to prevent
the restart.  This adds the upgrade code back into the update
and upgrade scripts.

Related-Bug: 1669714
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/q/59e5f9597eb37f69045e470eb457b878728477d7
Change-Id: I3e5899e2d831b89745b2f37e61ff69dbf83ff595
(cherry picked from commit 2e7c850fa1d78f2b21e5017e03b15a066a0666da)

commit_message:
Fix some api field lists in docstrings

Probably the most common format for documenting arguments is api field lists [1].
This change updates some docstrings to comply with the field lists syntax.

[1] http://sphinx-doc.org/domains.html#info-field-lists

Change-Id: Id3477a96eefccf826f7a07329280df1b1eaeb528

subject: 3PAR: Enable HPE-3PAR Compression Feature
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-09 12:44:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/13906776d196cacf6427a20ed2f2971f6be1e817', 'message': '3PAR: Enable HPE-3PAR Compression Feature

3PAR provides tpvv/tdvv provisioned volume types to be compressed.

This blueprint adds following functionalities

* Creating thin/dedup compresssed volume.

* Retype for already exsting tpvv/tdvv volumes to be compressed.

* Migration of compressed volumes.

Limitation:

Full provisioned volumes can not be compressed. To enable compression
on tpvv/tdvv atleast 16 GiB of volume size is needed.

Change-Id: I6f9261ec893f714766f1500382ad830e3aa38c92
Implements: 3par-compression-enable-support

commit_message:
3PAR: Enable HPE-3PAR Compression Feature

3PAR provides tpvv/tdvv provisioned volume types to be compressed.

This adds following functionalities

* Creating thin/dedup compresssed volume.

* Retype for already exsting tpvv/tdvv volumes to be compressed.

* Migration of compressed volumes.

* Create compressed volume from compressed volume/snapshot source

* Compression support to create cg from source

Change-Id: I6f9261ec893f714766f1500382ad830e3aa38c92
Implements: blueprint 3par-compression-enable-support

commit_message:
Implement list_concat function

This function uses python's extend function for lists in order to
concatenate lists. So, given the input: [['v1', 'v2'], ['v3', 'v4']]
the result would be ['v1', 'v2', 'v3', 'v4'].

This comes as an alternative to using yaql's concat.

Change-Id: I082833e73388540b29f71b78293fd36fe04b7b92

added_lines: def test_list_extend(self): snippet = {'list_extend': [['v1', 'v2'], ['v3', 'v4']]} snippet_resolved = ['v1', 'v2', 'v3', 'v4'] tmpl = template.Template(hot_pike_tpl_empty) resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl) self.assertEqual(snippet_resolved, resolved) def test_list_extend_none(self): snippet = {'list_extend': [['v1', 'v2'], ['v3', 'v4'], None]} snippet_resolved = ['v1', 'v2', 'v3', 'v4'] tmpl = template.Template(hot_pike_tpl_empty) resolved = self.resolve(snippet, tmpl) self.assertEqual(snippet_resolved, resolved) def test_list_extend_invalid(self): snippet = {'list_extend': [{'k1': 'v2'}, ['v3', 'v4']]} tmpl = template.Template(hot_pike_tpl_empty) exc = self.assertRaises(TypeError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('Incorrect arguments', six.text_type(exc))

commit_message:
Add layer 2 agent for Hyper-V Network Virtualization v2

The new layer 2 agent is required in order to interact with
the Microsoft Network Controller.

Co-Authored-By: Claudiu Belu <cbelu@cloudbasesolutions.com>

Partially-Implements: blueprint hyperv-network-virtualization-support

Change-Id: I019a4dca52881ab7eba895b85c039c8405da0628
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-hyperv refs/changes/86/436486/56 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron-hnv-agent = hyperv.neutron.hnv_agent:main

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-19 10:23:10.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/token-flush-twice-a-day-d4b00a2953a6b383.yaml', 'puppet/services/keystone.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/c1fc74c0f3a8ba34032ac40ee67ef3bc4b7c9d3e', 'message': "Run token flush cron job hourly by default

commit_message:
Run token flush cron job hourly by default

Running this job once a day has proven problematic for large
deployments as seen in the bug report. Setting it to run hourly
would be an improvement to the current situation, as the flushes
wouldn't need to process as much data.

Note that this only affects people using UUID as the token provider.

Change-Id: I462e4da2bfdbcba0403ecde5d613386938e2283a
Related-Bug: #1649616
(cherry picked from commit 65e643aca2202f031db94f1ccd3d44e195e5e772)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/05/458005/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default: '*'

subject: Use NULL as creator in ResourceUUID conversion
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-21 07:19:27.000000000', 'files': ['gnocchi/utils.py', 'gnocchi/tests/test_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/89c9170731de528015c10a3426ea53f188c99705', 'message': "Use NULL as creator in ResourceUUID conversion

In older versions of Gnocchi, the creator could be null. It's unlikely now as
all auth helper returns a string as creator, but it's still possible in theory.
This patch uses the NULL string as the creator is it's None (so NULL in SQL).

Change-Id: Id1faa16512b995fa2cd24ca4bed7912934cb5aad
Closes-Bug: #1684246
(cherry picked from commit 75e420673159fcf4a383f130e1652243fccc2b75)
"}]
commit_message:
Use NULL as creator in ResourceUUID conversion

In older versions of Gnocchi, the creator could be null. It's unlikely now as
all auth helper returns a string as creator, but it's still possible in theory.
This patch uses the NULL string as the creator is it's None (so NULL in SQL).

Change-Id: Id1faa16512b995fa2cd24ca4bed7912934cb5aad
Closes-Bug: #1684246
(cherry picked from commit 75e420673159fcf4a383f130e1652243fccc2b75)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/44/458744/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import uuid class TestResourceUUID(tests_base.TestCase): def test_conversion(self): self.assertEqual( uuid.UUID('ba571521-1de6-5aff-b183-1535fd6eb5d0'), utils.ResourceUUID( uuid.UUID('ba571521-1de6-5aff-b183-1535fd6eb5d0'), "bar")) self.assertEqual( uuid.UUID('ba571521-1de6-5aff-b183-1535fd6eb5d0'), utils.ResourceUUID("foo", "bar")) self.assertEqual( uuid.UUID('4efb21f6-3d19-5fe3-910b-be8f0f727846'), utils.ResourceUUID("foo", None)) self.assertEqual( uuid.UUID('853e5c64-f45e-58b2-999c-96df856fbe3d'), utils.ResourceUUID("foo", ""))

subject: Fixes crash Neutron OVS Agent to set tags for ports on Windows
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-06 18:16:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8db50aa5845f9d3555e36fad5cbec07ab1131f90', 'message': 'Fixes crash Neutron OVS Agent to set tags for ports on Windows

The Neutron OVS agent on Windows does not set the vlan/vxlan
tags for the VM ports when using the native implementation.
(using ovsdb_interface = native and of_interface = native)

This happens because: the agent will try to fetch a row
by record. It will check to see if it is a UUID, if the condition
is true it will try to fetch the column directly.

On Windows the name of the ports is a UUID (for Windows
there is no 16 chars length limitation as for Linux).
Since the UUID check will pass, it will try to fetch the
column directly instead of using the lookup table on
Windows and will raise RowNotFound exception.

This patch addresses this issue by removing the exception
RowNotFound in the Windows case; the rule will be fetched
using the lookup table.

Change-Id: Ie0a980eaf2a6956072c2536274252764aadd227d
Closes-Bug: #1670451

commit_message:
Fixes crash Neutron OVS Agent to set tags for ports on Windows

The Neutron OVS agent on Windows does not set the vlan
tags for the VM ports when using the native implementation.
(using ovsdb_interface = native and of_interface = native)

This happens because: the agent will try to fetch a row
by record. It will check to see if it is a UUID, if the condition
is true it will try to fetch the column directly.

On Windows the name of the ports is a UUID (for Windows
there is no 16 chars length limitation as for Linux).
Since the UUID check will pass, it will try to fetch the
column directly instead of using the lookup table on
Windows and will raise RowNotFound exception.

This patch addresses this issue by removing the exception
RowNotFound in the Windows case; the rule will be fetched
using the lookup table.

Change-Id: Ie0a980eaf2a6956072c2536274252764aadd227d
Closes-Bug: #1670451
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/01/442101/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys if sys.platform != 'win32': # On Windows the name of the ports is described by the OVS schema: # https://tinyurl.com/zk8skhx # Is a UUID. (This is due to the fact on Windows port names don't # have the 16 chars length limitation as for Linux). Because of # this the previous if condition will return true and will try # to fetch directly the column instead of using the lookup table. raise RowNotFound(table=table, col='uuid', match=record)

commit_message:
s3: use a single bucket for aggregate storage

s3 has a bucket limit so we can't just create a bucket per metric.
s3 has some partitioning logic to divide a bucket based on prefix[1]
so let us use the metric as a prefix of the object key.

[1] https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/amazon-s3-performance-tips-tricks-seattle-hiring-event/

Change-Id: If4a1ec3345d85a9937b4961b0ef61751b0a5e90d
Closes-Bug: #1671925

commit_message:
Add 'basename' filter

This is useful for setting the RPM Source tag to a local url. Eg

Source: {{ source|basename }}

where {{ source }} is a full url.

Change-Id: I94e2de1ea4bd7559b9f0d15a452156d0f3c9916a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/renderspec refs/changes/50/458750/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: context filter `basename` ************************* This is a filter which just returns ```os.path.basename()```:: {% set source = fetch_source('http://tarballs.openstack.org/oslo.log/oslo.log-master.tar.gz') %} Source0: {{ source|basename }} which then renders to:: Source0: oslo.log-master.tar.gz

commit_message:
drop _delete_unaggregated_timeserie

it's not used anywhere:
- file driver just deletes entire folder
- ceph driver just deletes as part of _delete_metric as unaggregated
object is what contains omaps references to aggregate objects

Change-Id: I83dfe73e8256dfa12df346b9615b3f2874e96773

commit_message:
Add popular ip protocols name in security group

Currently, ip protocols are specified as integer
in security group. However, due to a recent commit[1],
 most of the useful ip protocols are supported and can be
specified by its common name in neutron.
If horizon can support it,
it will greatly help ease the input of various ip protocols.
[1]https://review.openstack.org/#/c/259037/

Change-Id: I1410e55eafdb1ff60b188f8e5b5a8bc651f2a3f9
closes-bug:#1547998

commit_message:
fullstack: Compile openvswitch module for fullstack test

After switching to UCA, we started getting ovs 2.5.2. There was a
condition that compiled openvswitch only if the version was lower than
2.5.1. This patch always compiles only kernel part of openvswitch so we
get VXLAN tunnelling working with fullstack.

Closes-bug: 1684897

Change-Id: I13898fc661d590609d2ef40873daef987956db6b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/91/458591/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # prepare_for_compilation() - Fetch ovs git repository and install packages needed for # compilation. function prepare_for_compilation {} # compile_ovs() - Compile OVS from source and load needed modules. # Accepts two parameters: # - first one is True by default and means that modules are built and installed. # - second optional parameter defines prefix for ovs compilation # - third optional parameter defines localstatedir for ovs single machine runtime # Env variables OVS_REPO_NAME, OVS_REPO and OVS_BRANCH must be set function compile_ovs { local _pwd=$PWD local build_modules=${1:-True} local prefix=$2 local localstatedir=$3 if [ -n "$prefix" ]; then prefix="--prefix=$prefix" fi if [ -n "$localstatedir" ]; then localstatedir="--localstatedir=$localstatedir" fi prepare_for_compilation# action_service - call an action over openvswitch service # Accepts one parameter that can be either # 'start', 'restart' and 'stop'. function action_openvswitch { local action=$1 if is_ubuntu; then ${action}_service openvswitch-switch elif is_fedora; then ${action}_service openvswitch elif is_suse; then if [[ $DISTRO == "sle12" ]] && [[ $os_RELEASE -lt 12.2 ]]; then ${action}_service openvswitch-switch else ${action}_service openvswitch fi fi } # compile_ovs_kernel_module() - Compile openvswitch kernel module and load it function compile_ovs_kernel_module { local _pwd=$PWD prepare_for_compilation if [ ! -f config.status ] || [ configure -nt config.status ] ; then ./configure --with-linux=/lib/modules/$(uname -r)/build fi action_openvswitch stop make -j$[$(nproc) + 1] sudo make INSTALL_MOD_DIR=kernel/net/openvswitch modules_install if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then sudo modprobe -r vport_geneve sudo modprobe -r openvswitch load_module openvswitch load_module vport-geneve False dmesg | tail else echo "Compiling OVS kernel module failed" fi action_openvswitch start cd $_pwd }
deleted_lines: # compile_ovs() - Compile OVS from source and load needed modules. # Accepts two parameters: # - first one is True by default and means that modules are built and installed. # - second optional parameter defines prefix for ovs compilation # - third optional parameter defines localstatedir for ovs single machine runtime # Env variables OVS_REPO_NAME, OVS_REPO and OVS_BRANCH must be set function compile_ovs { local _pwd=$PWD local build_modules=${1:-True} local prefix=$2 local localstatedir=$3 if [ -n "$prefix" ]; then prefix="--prefix=$prefix" fi if [ -n "$localstatedir" ]; then localstatedir="--localstatedir=$localstatedir" fi

commit_message:
Update fakeha net-iso configuration

We added the storage-mgmt network to the ipv4 ci net-iso templates
to support hyperconverged ceph, but this means that all jobs using
the ipv4 templates need to be using the custom
network-isolation-absolute.yaml as well.  This one was missed in
the original patch.

Change-Id: I7f78d43ea60f3d8e9ea5819aadf94fc28695b638
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/96/458596/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
glance: deploy services with Keystone v3 endpoints

* Switch auth_uri to point to Keystone versionless endpoint.
* Switch Swift auth url to use Keystone versionless endpoint and
  Keystone v3 API.

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I78cdd2286b5a5094f36d4f3c7c58340745664449
Partial-blueprint: keystone-v3

commit_message:
trivial: Add note about multiple builders support

Sphinx 1.6 will support the definition of multiple builders in a
setup.cfg file like so:

  [build_sphinx]
  builder = html man

Once we support this version of Sphinx, we should stop carrying the
custom versions of this tooling we use.

Upstreaming things FTW.

Change-Id: Ibf2a003229a4585df96b09da7ca547e201c5aef5

commit_message:
Return the full path when searching for archive files

Otherwise it is impossible for utils._extract_archive_to_tempdir() where
to look for an archive.

Change-Id: Ie066655589c0582c11fe5a440de15a1fb7fcce69

commit_message:
save_and_reraise_exception() instead of raise

Instead of simply re-'raise'ing the exception, this uses oslo_utils'
excutils.save_and_reraise_exception() -- to handles cases where
the exception context might be cleared.

Change-Id: Ibfa26e8b1b4dd760b6de4321457593c8479d774d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/35/458235/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use NULL as creator in ResourceUUID conversion

In older versions of Gnocchi, the creator could be null. It's unlikely now as
all auth helper returns a string as creator, but it's still possible in theory.
This patch uses the NULL string as the creator is it's None (so NULL in SQL).

Change-Id: Id1faa16512b995fa2cd24ca4bed7912934cb5aad
Closes-Bug: #1684246

commit_message:
Update Dell EMC Cinder back end services

and to the Controller role (defaulting to OS::Heat::None).

(cherry picked from commit 5fb637c611c3c8c4daf8e8d2f06d5579b9ef34fd)

commit_message:
Enable non-apache devstack job for Mistral

The Mistral devstack plugin now defualts to using apache for wsgi. This
patch adds a non-apache (non-voting) job.

Change-Id: Ie23a8cff367071362369df3f38d82e32a161cd24
Depends-On: I953dbdab71029b392f8846c50fa3d801c293cc5a

commit_message:
BlockDevice - pass command line arguments directly

To avoid the number of arguments to BlockDevice.__init__() exploding,
pass the argument results directly.

Set the default config from argparse to reduce an init step

Change-Id: I0d3b3715ed7d92b0aa97eab24fb7304a62bc2c0a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/27/458727/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Default configuration: # one image, one partition, mounted under '/' DEFAULT_CONFIG_JSON = """ - local_loop: name: image0 """ def __init__(self, args): logger.debug("Build dir [%s]" % args.build_dir) self.config = yaml.safe_load(self.config) logger.debug("Parsed config [%s]" % self.config) # XXX: explain this dictionary self.default_config = { 'image_size': args.image_size, 'image_dir': args.image_dir } self.state_dir = os.path.join(args.build_dir,

commit_message:
Re-order plugins in collectd-ceiloemter-plugin job

Gnocchi/ceiloemter and aodh need to be configured and enabled before
collectd starts, so that the collectd-ceiloemter-plugin does not hit
errors trying to submit metric/raise alarms using the services.

Change-Id: If7b4a42f27c7b004a6f60b9b9792a1a5ca670b0f

commit_message:
Enable nova in kuryr fullstack and rally test

Public endpoint for compute service not find in Kuryr rally job.
This is because in kuryr rally test, we did not enable nova.
This patch enable kuryr related service with  default services.

Change-Id: Ib817680b5a9ffaa1238cdbb1047e61f575736093
Closes-bug: #1683153

commit_message:
Create heat-specific patrole gate

Creates a heat-specific patrole gate, because heat's policy.json
uses different roles than most projects: heat_stack_user, in
particular.

Change-Id: I05a53ce80453b7488233bf765951837a3d86209f

commit_message:
SSHD Service extensions

This change implements a MOTD message and provides a hash of
sshd config options which are sourced to the puppet-ssh module
as a hash.

The SSHD puppet service is enabled by default, as it is
required for Idb56acd1e1ecb5a5fd4d942969be428cc9cbe293.
Also added the service to the CI roles.

Change-Id: Ie2e01d93082509b8ede37297067eab03bb1ab06e
Depends-On: I1d09530d69e42c0c36311789166554a889e46556
Closes-Bug: #1668543
Co-Authored-By: Oliver Walsh <owalsh@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/22/444622/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parameter_defaults: MOTD: | ALERT! You are entering into a secured area! Your IP, Login Time, Username has been noted and has been sent to the server administrator! This service is restricted to authorized users only. All activities on this system are logged. Unauthorized access will be fully investigated and reported to the appropriate law enforcement agencies.

commit_message:
Add composable role support for NetApp Cinder back end

Convert NetApp Cinder back end to support composable roles via new
"CinderBackendNetApp" service.

Closes-Bug: #1680568
Change-Id: Ia3a78a48c32997c9d3cbe1629c2043cfc5249e1c
(cherry picked from commit c533a3219e47c5a6155e85e089b9f8acdb4a3dd6)

by tox and the start and finish time for each test which can be useful

commit_message:
jenkins: scripts: run-tox.sh: Increase verbosity

Level 2 verbosity gives some useful output such as the PATH that's used
by tox and the start and finish time for each test which can be useful
when debugging tox related issues. Other than that, the output is very
similar to that of level 1.

Change-Id: I34a82bf45546e7b1b6265ecf8a7e9fd73a6cb3a9
Link: https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=verbosity2&type=
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/09/457709/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tox -vv -e$venv

commit_message:
Add mosquitto grafana dashboard

Now that we have stats reporting into statsd from the mosquitto broker
lets add a grafana dashboard to track that data. This is a first pass at
the dashboard I expect we'll have to update and refine it before we can
get useful metrics from it.

Change-Id: I1c4bc8fc8df544d95ec3711a065d88ec17df4078

commit_message:
gnocchi: fix functional tests on master

The change I7a4f96511efdd4151c87e23cb3ff131f62418603 does not work as
expected, an old rule override the new one.

This changes fixes that.

commit_message:
Make octavia scenario jobs voting

This patch makes the octavia v1 scenario gates voting.
It also fixes the scenario gate skips for documentation patches to skip
all of the current scenario gates and skip is the change is only in the
api-ref path.

Change-Id: Ica538b2597fd61d25269bb40d48b968d8898a591

commit_message:
Remove trusty jobs from nova experimental queue

Trusty is only used in mitaka jobs and mitaka is end of
life basically, so we can drop these from the nova
experimental queue now.

Remove a job definition that is unused now.

Change-Id: I800998f4110a914233dca376a52fdb97f40872d1

commit_message:
Update OSC baremetal node set/unset supporting dynamic drivers

Update OSC baremetal node set and unset to support setting the
hardware interfaces boot, console, deploy, inspect, management,
power, raid, and vendor for a node.

Change-Id: I70514b8cb5968703854e23739e0a380783df5378

commit_message:
Fix themable image choicefield display text bug

Following a recent patch [0], image choicefields with themable
widgets are not rendering display correctly.

This patch fixes the bug, correctly formatting the image display
names.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/452771/

Change-Id: Ide558af94cd1484f7bada414658da5d1319ab384
Closes-Bug: #1684141

commit_message:
Use the ovsdbapp library

This patch uses the ovsdbapp Python library, which is the new
project based on the Neutron OVSDB API.

The CLI implementation of the OVSDB API remains in the Neutron
tree.

Neutron continues providing the (deprecated) ability to allow
the OVSDB API to be imported from Neutron.

The deleted tests exist in the ovsdbapp project. More will be
moved later, but many of the tests in the Neutron tree use
ovs_lib, which doesn't exist in ovsdbapp so those tests will
probably stay in the Neutron tree.

Closes-Bug: #1684277
Depends-On: I3d3535b1d6fe37c78a9399903b65bbd688b1c4b9
Change-Id: Ic8c7db0e80d0ad104242322d3f1f70cab8caab92

commit_message:
Update ovsdbapp requirement to 0.3.0

Previous releases had issues revealed during integration into Neutron.
The library is not currently consumed by any other project, so the bump
should not affect anyone.

The patch that integrates the new release with Neutron is:
Ic8c7db0e80d0ad104242322d3f1f70cab8caab92

Change-Id: I3d3535b1d6fe37c78a9399903b65bbd688b1c4b9

commit_message:
Neutron server was not compatible with member actions

Register a new extension into Neutron server, and this extension
contains a member action. if new member action contains the "update"
string. As a result, Neutron server check the target whether contains
"ATTRIBUTES_TO_UPDATE". Because this is a member action so that neutron
server will not go "_update" method normally but "_handle_action"
method. So the exception happens KeyError: 'attributes_to_update'.

Co-Authored-By: zhang ping<ping.zhang@easystack.cn>
Change-Id: Ie8bb7b9af42a82aada28d2bcdfd5b0e573ad9778
Closes-Bug: #1606455

commit_message:
drop scheduler process

as we move to multiple buckets, we will let each worker figure out
it's whether a bucket needs to be processed and thus we don't need a
central scheduler to distribute work around. for now, all workers
will go ham and work on same bucket.

Change-Id: I659f93545961b2943902eaefe7c7bd622abdc42f

commit_message:
drop single bucket partitioning

as we move to multiple buckets, we want workers to process buckets
completely. this removes any internal bucket partitioning as
first step

Change-Id: I4ac40688e3069965d5899ae024d3183989e281e9

commit_message:
Add oslo_messaging to the list of log levels

The namespace name (oslo.messaging) is set to INFO, but we don't do it
with the oslo_messaging package name. It logs with both prefix, so we
should set INFO on both.

Change-Id: Ia8e53b0b40dd546abecc73abe855939200167ee8

commit_message:
Replace references to the 192.0.2 network

Following change I1393d65ffb20b1396ff068def237418958ed3289 the ctlplane
network will be 192.168.24 by default and not 192.0.2 anymore.

This change removes old references left to 192.0.2 network from the
overcloud templates.

(cherry picked from commit b5b6681a74e001448a836e7eea5e75fba859b88c)
Closes-Bug: #1682144
Change-Id: I49bd1ac8d594105665010bd898670b17e72fa763

commit_message:
Move ceilometer wsgi to step 3

Apache is configured in step 3 so if we configure ceilometer in step 4,
the configuration is removed on updates. We need to configure it in step
3 with the other apache services to ensure we don't have issues on
updates.

Change-Id: Icc9d03cd8904c93cb6e17f662f141c6e4c0bf423
Related-Bug: #1664418
(cherry picked from commit 890178bd6f6f465ffcb8cf4ad9b8019a1d6dc653)

commit_message:
Add write tests docs for using client managers and credentials

This commit adds documentation on how to interact with clients, client
managers, and credentials objects. These are critical pieces of
information for anyone writing tempest tests, so making sure the guide
includes this information is equally important.

Change-Id: I89e2c137068eea8aeaff0561fe078eccd3a23f0e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/99/455099/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _credentials: Interacting with Credentials and Clients ======================================== Once you have your basic TestCase setup you'll want to start writing tests. To do that you need to interact with an OpenStack deployment. This section will cover how credentials and clients are used inside of Tempest tests. Manager Objects --------------- The primary interface with which you interact with both credentials and API clients is the client manager object. These objects are created automatically by the base test class as part of credential setup. (for more details see the previous :ref:`credentials`_ section) Each manager object is initialized with a set of credentials and has each client object already setup to use that set of credentials for making all the api requests. Each client is accessible as a top level attribute on the manager object. So to start making api requests you just access the client's method for making that call and the credentials are already setup for you. For example if you wanted to make an API call to create a server in Nova:: from tempest import test class TestExampleCase(test.BaseTestCase): def test_example_create_server(self): self.os.servers_client.create_server(...) is all you need to do. As decribed previously, in the above example the self.os is created automatically because the base test class sets the ``credentials`` attribute to allocate a primary credential set and initializes the client manager as ``self.os``. This same access pattern can be used for all of the clients in Tempest. Credentials Objects ------------------- In certain cases you need direct access to the credentials. (the most common use case would be an API request that takes a user or project id in the request body) If you're in a situation where you need to access this you'll need to access the ``credentials`` object which is allocated from the configured credential provider in the base test class. This is accessible from the manager object via the manager's credentials attribute. For example:: from tempest import test class TestExampleCase(test.BaseTestCase): def test_example_create_server(self): credentials = self.os.credentials

commit_message:
Use base.setup_test_tenant to create test tenant

This is to add **kwargs in base.setup_test_tenant in order
that it can be more widely used in testcases to create
test tenant, so to make code clean.

Change-Id: I7841dd88e240a730da26384ac9ee2801ef1757f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/61/458361/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def setup_test_tenant(self, **kwargs): if 'name' not in kwargs: kwargs['name'] = data_utils.rand_name('test_tenant') if 'description' not in kwargs: kwargs['description'] = data_utils.rand_name('desc') tenant = self.projects_client.create_tenant(**kwargs)['tenant']
